title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the National Anti-Drug Media Campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to rename it the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act. This includes provisions for a national media campaign aimed at preventing drug abuse among young people. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act aims to prevent drug abuse among young people in the United States by increasing awareness and encouraging discussions about the dangers of drug use. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the purposes and strategy of the national media campaign. The Director is responsible for implementing the campaign, approving the strategy and advertising used. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, determines the purposes and strategy of the national media campaign, including the purchase of advertising time and space. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America recommends strategies to address national, regional, and local drug threats and creates advertising for the campaign. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, determines the purposes and strategy of the national media campaign, including creating advertising for the campaign, except for ads provided by other nonprofits or intended for specific audiences that cannot be reached at no cost. The Director will test all advertisements before using them in the national media campaign to ensure effectiveness and meet industry standards. A media buying contractor will be hired to plan and purchase advertising time and space. The Director will test all advertisements before using them in the national media campaign to ensure effectiveness and meet industry standards. A media buying contractor will plan and purchase advertising time and space, including strategic planning and accounting for such purchases. The Director will ensure that sufficient funds are allocated for advertising in the national media campaign, with the option to designate the Office of National Drug Control Policy or its designee for this purpose. The Director must allocate enough funds for the national media campaign's goals. No funds can be used for creative ad development, except for reaching specific audiences that cannot be reached at no cost. The Director must allocate funds for the national media campaign's goals, with restrictions on creative ad development. Amendments include notifying specific committees of any changes. Amounts for the national media campaign under section 106 must require a no cost match of equivalent value of advertising broadcast time and print space or in-kind contributions. The Director must ensure that all no cost matches of advertising material, time, and space directly relate to substance abuse prevention for the national media campaign. Advertising material donated at no cost should have sponsorship identification. The Director must ensure that a minimum of 85% of funds appropriated for the national media campaign is used for purchasing advertising time and space. Additionally, no more than $5,000,000 should be used annually. The Director must ensure that at least 85% of funds for the national media campaign go towards purchasing advertising time and space, with a cap of $5,000,000 annually for developing advertising material. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits and examinations of records as specified in the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act. An independent entity must evaluate the effectiveness of the national media campaign annually based on data from the 'Monitoring the Future Study' by the Department of Health and Human Services. The Director must evaluate the national media campaign annually using data from various studies, including the Attitude Tracking Study and the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, and submit a report to Congress. The Director must evaluate the national media campaign annually using data from various studies and submit a report to Congress. Section 105 is amended to include the evaluation referred to in paragraph (2). The Director must evaluate the national media campaign annually and submit a report to Congress. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign strategy, accomplishments, efficiency measures, advertising plans, and financial accountability policies. Contracts with corporations, partnerships, or individuals working on behalf of the campaign must be transparent to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. Authorization of $195,000,000 annually for the Office of National Drug Control Policy from 2004 to 2008.
